pros: I liked my coworkers. That is about the only thing I can think of.
cons: I was a 40 something woman doing a clerk job. I had hoped it would be possible to move up if I did a good job. I alwasy got good reviews UNTIL a Mr. Perfect -- who was in his twenties -- came along. My boss was so enamored of him that he got promoted to Bibliographic assistant even though he had been there less than a year and I had been slogging it out for five.... spinning my wheels in this boring, repetitive job for no good reason. By then I understood that there was no such thing as getting promoted into a new job that would create yet another vacancy, but that I could at least hope to have my job "reclassified to something resembling a living wage. In the five years I was there, my weekly pay went from something like $12.16 an hour to $12.50 (and they nullified that meager little crumb by making us pay an extra $20 per month for our health insurance). Mr. Perfect started as a clerk and was immediately hired into a plum Bibliographic Assitant job that paid at least $20 an hour which did not seem so bad then. I would have killed for it. But I was told there was not enough money in the budget and that "we really really appreciate everyone." Another person was also given the same "raise" but she had at least been there for two years. I got so angry that I quit the job within the year, and so did Mr. Perfect.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Working at an R1 school is a huge pro. It helps a lot with networking when you attend conferences, and it can be a boon to getting presentation proposals accepted. The student population at Temple makes for a very rewarding daily work experience. Temple has a very diverse student body that includes first-gen students, low-income students, students coming out of the foster care system, and of course students of color. Temple also puts its money where its mouth is with regard to accessibility services, so there is a good representation of students with disabilities. The benefits are good, including being able to use tuition remission. You can use pre-tax income to pay for a SEPTA pass, and there are a number of service discounts for all sorts of things. Because Temple is massive, it makes it easy to move from one job to another as you grow in your career. If you're interested in a career shift, you can do so within the university. The people on the ground at the university are generally phenomenal. Once working there for a while, you learn contacts and people are very open to providing inter-department support and collaboration.
cons: Temple doesn't pay as much as other R1 schools in Philly. As such there's a lot of staff turnover. It's not a well-kept secret that Temple hires new professionals in the field of student services, and those folks tend to move on. This can be frustrating when trying to maintain a list of university contacts. Tuition remission, while nice, can be severely limited. Every department can make its own rules regarding whether employees are allowed to take classes during the day. Taking this into account, your total program options become very narrow. Grad-level classes are subject to taxed income, which can be an issue when you consider that Temple pays lower than other R1 schools locally. The university is massive, so administrative decisions can be very disconnected from lower-level employee experience. This was a nightmare during the pandemic, with each department making wildly different decisions. Lack of support for professional development. Budget cuts have led many departments to slash their conference budget. They'll still pay your salary to attend, but you have to foot the travel bill. As diverse as the university is, there's still a lack of support for staff belonging to religious minority groups. This will vary across departments, of course. But something to keep an eye out for when interviewing.

pros:
The testing center has some very helpful and attentive supervisors - they were very willing to assist if you ever needed attention or questions answered. Otherwise, the position is fairly straightforward and you have tons of resources/testing manuals at your disposal to help you, so really most of the work is independent. Some days can be quite busy, but on other days you'll have time to complete school work, which is a plus. If you're not busy with testing, sometimes supervisors will assign extra administrative tasks - this is a great way to get general administrative experience in general.

Also, another fantastic reason to work for the testing center is that you're paid separately by testing companies if you work over the weekend. Normally pay is quite good for these extra exams if you can fit them in your schedule (it's not required necessarily, but most of the proctors expect and want to work the occasional weekend)!
cons:
Sometimes testing can be chaotic - this is just part of being a test proctor, though, and not unique to Temple's testing center. A good deal of your work is done alone - which can be nice if it's a slow testing day - but stressful and overwhelming if you have a line out the door and can hardly catch a break. 

Also, there is little opportunity to advance from this position. I knew some coworkers who had this position for many years but still never got a salary raise or promotion to a different position within the center. Opportunities to get a full time position in the testing company do come up (rarely), but for the most part this is ideally a job for a grad student or retiree who just wants to work part time.

review_title: Good place to work if you need a graduate degree or if you're at the end of your career
pros: Temple offers steady employment (even in this economy, universities are trying not to lay anyone off), great benefits (health insurance, a generous match in their 401(k) equivalent (403(b)), life and disability insurance, excellent vacation policy, tuition reimbursement for both employee and immediate family members, etc.). If you need to earn another degree, it's perfect-- its graduate programs are stronger than the undergrad program, and the class schedule is flexible. Temple is a dynamic and diverse university located within a gritty Philadelphia neighborhood. Working there roots you in the city, its people, and its interesting programs. It's exciting to work for and with talented students and faculty.
cons: Despite its many positives, Temple, like any university, is a large and slow bureaucracy, with all the associated drawbacks. Although co-workers are lovely, in many departments they have worked in the same position for decade, creating an atmosphere of apathy and sometimes even entitlement. Presidents Adamany and Hart have worked to create a more professional atmosphere, but it will be several years before taking full effect. Another issue is the lack of young professional development-- the work force trends older and therefore youth is sometimes distrusted and overlooked (ironic for a university). The university therefore loses young employees to private industry.

Its really sad because TU pushes this concept of customer service called the "TU Way" but its obviously not happening internally. Having been a former customer service rep, I do everything I can to remain calm, understanding, and patient on the phone and despite the bored sighs, the tones of exasperation, and being transferred without being asked or even told I was going to be moved to a different department...I have been nothing but kind. Still, I guess this is the way of the world these days.

review_title: Overall, a strong and decently-run university
job_title: Director of Marketing and Communications in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
The university is well-run and well-resourced overall. The general atmosphere is one of things generally getting better, which is nice--support systems and resources are abundant, and while not perfect, they seem to work pretty well and the people who make them run generally seem to want to continue improving them. In the college where I worked, it felt like those who were hard-working, smart and ambitious were given a good amount of support and opportunities to continue building the initiatives they were working on. As a whole, Temple is a large enough place that there are opportunities to move to different positions within the university. 

Sure, there are competing interests and conflicting ideas about how to do things best, and there were things about working there that weren't ideal, but compared to other universities/organizations, I think Temple can be a great place to grow professionally.
cons: The university has had some significant and highly public missteps in the past several years. The deans of the individual colleges within the university also have a huge amount of power and discretion over the operations of their colleges, and while this can be a great thing for some (if your dean is serious about investing in centralized functions, for instance), it may not be as beneficial for those at smaller colleges or units.

pros: Provides opportunities to job seekers

pros: As an entry level associate its a good company. It gets you acclimated to customer service , security and professionalism in a corporate setting. they paid  on average or a little higher than other entry level security companies.
cons:
they don't rotate uniforms very often on site. they only provide 2 sets of uniforms for full time staff ,and the uniforms although they look okay when you first receive them they tend to get beat up so if you don't pay the dry cleaners every week  you'll begin to get dingy.
the hours are many be full time on paper but during summer & winter they feel seasonal, they say that hey offer other places to make up hours but the sites are few and far in between.
there is no overnight differential even though i'm pretty sure there is a law against not having one.
the officers are scared of supervisors who are scared of management  all because people aren't dealt with because of bad conduct but because of how the person is feeling that day.

review_title: Temple University's academic environment nurtures and challenges students, faculty and staff beyond the classroom.
pros: The learning environment at Temple invites and challenges anyone in the pursuit of knowledge, inside and outside of the classroom for faculty and students.  This inspires and creates a venue to discuss and debate politics, science, literature, art, current events, and serves to encourage not just students and professors, but also, staff members, visiting scholars, alumni and members of the community.
cons: There is a disconnect between senior executives and the rank and file because the mandates are muddled by competing senior managers in all areas, including administrative units, academic departments and the management of the facility.  But the Human Resource department is considered ineffective and disorganized throughout the entire university.

review_title: Great benefits, but experience depends on department
pros: Great benefits--finish your degree for free, good healthcare, fair leave and pension benefits, great (and cheap!) cultural enrichment available right there on campus, great food if you avoid anything by the on-campus food vendor (which is appallingly bad and incredibly overpriced).
cons: Some of the departments are quite dysfunctional. Most of the time, this is a supervision issue, because supervisors can't be bothered to actually supervise, and laziness/slacking off/not caring has become ingrained into the culture of many departments, such that it's actually easier to do things yourself (that you are not supposed to do) than get the people who ARE supposed to do them to do them.

pros: Temple has a diverse and exciting campus environment enhanced by the tremendous growth in its resident population. Persons who've not been to campus in the last 10 years will be surprised by the growth of its physical plant and the improvements in its academic programs ... business, law, communications, education, psychology to name a few ... and student profiles. Safety and security are a priority on campus (it is a city school after all), and it is less menacing and safer than comparable campuses in Philly and New York (have you been to Penn or Columbia?). Temple takes its role of populist educator to the region very seriously and supplies the area with most of its doctors, lawyers educators and entrepreneurs. It is no longer a subway stop on the road of life, as one student once famously wrote in the Princeton review. Temple gets in your blood.
cons: Sometimes too large for its own good.  Tries too hard to be all things to all people, but that is a good kind of con.

review_title: A truly diverse student population in an urban university attuned to the issues of the city
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: In recent years Temple has become an attractive urban campus carved out of what was once a dismal part of the city. Much of the credit goes to well conceived landscaping which provides attractive and abundant outdoor spaces. The student population is racially, socially and ethnically diverse in a manner that other universities try to claim but have not achieved.
cons:
For a reason that is not clear to me, the staff is less educated, less efficient and less skilled than staff at other area universities.  Customer service - if you will - is poor. This may be because of a reliance on student workers or because of a less than competitive pay scale.  The front line staff is unprofessional. Things do not run smoothly.
The well-known adjunct dilemma is no better here than elsewhere. Temple is as determined as other universities to mistreat adjuncts by denying them benefits and decent pay.

review_title: A vibrant and diverse community in one of the best cities in the US, with significant challenges to overcome
pros: Stable employment, actually diverse (real opportunities with fewer barriers based on race, gender, sexuality, national economic background, etc), mostly fantastic benefits for full-time employees (20 vacation days, 3 personal, plus a week winter break & 10 sick days - Blue Cross Personal Choice as an option for health insurance, 6 mostly-free credits per semester of courses (some charges apply), free tuition for employee's children, recognizes domestic partnerships, etc), plenty of opportunities for ambitious employees
cons: Stable employment is undercut by instability in academic departments, diversity does not protect against cliques and pervasive internal politics, upper management is increasingly dominated by non-academics, upper level administrators administer things they don't understand, opportunities for ambitious or dedicated employees are created largely by the apathy or negligence of other employees

pros: Nothing really made my time here
cons: Nobody cares about you at all

job_title: Senior Support Staff in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Good retirement benefits if you can make it 3 years without leaving--I could not. Good vacation time--you will need it.
cons:
In the Fox  School of Business there is way too much bureaucracy, very little camaraderie between departments and programs, and how something looks is often more important than how it functions. The top administrators in the college seemed very egotistical and not supportive of the rest of the university. 

My supervisors were not trained in the area of expertise that I was hired for, were very unsupportive of new ideas and industry standard practices, were very unprofessional in how they dealt with situations that didn't align with the plan in their heads that they didn't bother to share, and very poor at communicating clear goals and expectations. 

As a whole, very behind in flexible work schedule options as in there are none.

review_title: Great benefits and job security, conservative administration
pros: Employees have a great deal of job security and tuition remission, 401(k) and healthcare benefits are great.  There is a winter break holiday on top of regular holidays and vacation time is ample.  Work-life balance is good.  There are opportunities for lifelong learning, and human resources training is wonderful.  Certain managers are great.  It is difficult to be fired or dismissed.
cons: Administrative units and colleges tend to operate in silos, so the culture is inconsistent.  In my administrative department there seem to be many conservative values and lack of strategic planning, though this is not true of the University as a whole.  While employee loyalty is appreciated, it is also important to hold everyone equally accountable to their job duties, and this is not always done.  I am not valued by some as a female manager.

review_title: Working for Temple is a decent way to get experience, but it's certainly not cutting edge.
pros: It may help you become more marketable as you job search in the future, whether it is in IT, research, office-work, or operations.
cons: While you can gain valuable experience from your job, none of the positions here are certainly cutting edge. Many people are hired into positions that I wonder HOW they are competent for. You may not learn any new and useful skills, unless you ask for them.

pros: Benefits are excellent. You can finish or start your degree, and your children/spouse have benefit of using remission tuition. The environment is very diverse with many avenues for you to explore. I have been here for 10 years, and even though my unit has a demanding schedule our time is flexible and we are fairly self-starters without much micro-management.
cons: Long hours maybe a problem since projects are cumbersome. It is hard to advance if you are not a certain grade level. Compensation is very fair but hard to get merit bonuses or salary increases (outside cost of living) due to bootstrapped budgets.

review_title: If only there were a campus in Florida
job_title: Assistant Director of Graduate Enrollment in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I worked within the Fox School of Business and loved everything about my position, my team, and management. It was great working with such a collaborative team and management who listened to new ideas. Hours were great, week off between Christmas and New Years, work from home days, travel opportunities. The only reason I left was because I wanted to move back to Florida (too cold up north!).
cons: The only downside was the salary - I felt about 10k more would have been sufficient considering there was no overtime and there were nights we would have yield and admissions events. Health insurance was a little expensive since you only have the option of single or family (would be great if I had kids though, but not for myself and my spouse).

There is probably a good amount of variability in the experience of working between various colleges, however, consistently experienced lack of support and misinformation from management, and very much a lack of appreciation for the long days, and heavy caseloads being managed.

review_title: Overall, a fair institution if you can get through the red tape.
pros: Large university that functions like a small institution. Friendly faculty and staff, excellent branding that sometimes makes Temple appear more "red hot" than it actually is.
cons: Very outdated resources in terms of technology and human capital. Staff and faculty are unionized which makes it very difficult to achieve goals due to politics and outdated ways of doing simple tasks, no one is held accountable (I literally watched a woman sleep at her desk and no one disciplined her due to her being employed at Temple for 35+ years and active in her Union), financial model of RCM is not efficient, wasteful spending due to lack of communication between colleges/schools and departments.

pros: Loved this job clients and students I got a chance to share so much with each person I cam in contact with. My boss was the best I ever had. We worked well together. The program seems to grow each year.
cons: I created the two day guest pass that OLLI currently uses and the control issues need to be improved. Students are abusing the guest pass and people are going to class and not paying membership as others are and that is not fair to other members.

review_title: where unskilled office workers go to hide & talent goes to work on their resumé
pros: University is major presence in downtown Philadelphia. Benefits are decent and they employ a vast number of teachers, staff & administration. Easy to make office friendships with so many coworkers of various ages groups, diverse backgrounds & differing work histories.
cons: Like so many companies, it is hindered by inept upper management and office politics of general supervisors looking for promotions. If you are lucky to work in a dept that is drama free, hopefully you will get out before things change. Think of it as a 2 or 3-year stepping-stone to a better job. Any longer than that and the poison will start setting in.

pros: Very autonomous work environment with opportunities to get involved in many different aspects of the university.  Excellent benefits package with generous time off for non-union employees.
cons: Union positions limit employees significantly.  Compensation remains pretty flat once on board.  Compensation in general is low.  Leadership at the Business School is dysfunctional and leads to extremely high turnover.  Strategy is set with little to no thought and by handshakes made with leadership's cronies.  It's very fly by the seat of your pants-- front-line administrators then have to clean up the mess of a poorly thought out plan.

review_title: Underrated and under confident organization, needs new management
pros: The shining light of Temple are the students, as a professor they are the reason it is a good place to work.  Colleagues are quite good but administration puts too much pressure on them so collaboration is difficult.
cons: Poor uninspired management.  Temple succeeds despite the administration and very corrupt administrative culture.  Play the politics right and you are ok, no interest in politics good luck

A great place to work if you are looking to work for the full time and pursue a graduate degree

Job Stability for long term

review_title: Great Place for Research, Horrible Place for Work-Life Balance
job_title: Ph D Candidate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: This is one of the best research institutions in the state, if not the country, to do your Ph.D in. The research here is world renowned, and if you choose to stay in academia, this is an amazing place to jump off from.
cons: Long work hours, the professors can be potentially abusive and dump more work on you than you can handle. This can result in a dampening of your work-life balance. The deans of the graduate program don't listen to complaints about workplace abuse, and assume the students can handle it on their own.

pros: Temple wants to do good things for the youth of Philadelphia, and in many ways it does so.  It has very affordable tuition and is getting stronger as a school.  Many members of its upper-level management are passionate.
cons: There are a lot of institutional problems.  Like many higher educational institutions, people in management positions do not have any experience doing their jobs.  This is relatively common in higher ed, but is particularly bad at Temple.  Its culture of faculty governance and inability to hold a full staff make life very difficult for many employees, who are unheard when they voice concerns.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The lab I work in has a good positive environment for learning and scientific advancement. If you carefully select the lab you wish to work in as a post doc, you will be encouraged and have opportunities to improve you scientific knowledge and career. If you are not too careful, you will suffer.
cons: Can sometimes take a while for deparmental equipment to be fixed. Departmental restructing is creating friction among faculty, with a lot of facutly seeking reappointment in other Temple Centers or indeed alternative institutions.

review_title: The university's faculty is treated like "hired hands" by the administration.
pros:
Several locations in and around a great urban center.
Convenient public transportation to the Main Campus.
Majority of colleagues are great to work with.
Extended mid-winter (holidays) vacation period.
Makes a concerted effort to continually assess teaching effectiveness, especially at the undergraduate level.
cons:
The university uses an industrial administrative model that establishes an adversarial relationship between the faculty and central administration.  Far too much money is channeled into the various sports programs, rather than the school's primary instructional mission.  
For promotion and tenure, the reward system is tilted heavily toward research and published scholarship.

pros: Very laid-back environment; friendly supervisors and co-workers; very flexible schedules. For a student, like myself, it is easily accessible as the jobs is on the campus where I am most of the time anyway.
cons: Kind of frustrating at times when it gets busy and students complain for the simplest things that we have no control over. There are also some co-workers that are a bit belligerent about their jobs and make very common mistakes that are a hassle for the person taking over after them.

review_title: Great place to work in IT
pros:
Temple's Computer Services department is a great place to work. 

* There is tremendous diversity in technologies to work on; there are groups actively developing in .Net, Java, Perl, PHP, Drupal, PL/SQL, and dozens of other languages. If you've ever wanted to work on something, you can get an opportunity to do that, here. 
* The benefits are superb 
* The workload is fair; you will be kept busy, but you will typically not have to work long hours. 
* The other staff is great. 
* The atmosphere is generally fairly light
cons: * People stay for a long time, which is a good thing, but means opportunities for advancement may take a long time in developing

pros: Although pay isn't wonderful, there are many opportunities for professional development, especially with tuition remission.  I enjoy working in the higher ed environment and with students.  Beside tuition remission for employee and children, health benefits and matching retirement benefits are great.
cons: Depending on what department you are in, most employees are overworked.  There are a lot of students and not enough staff to service.  We do the best we can with the resources and student demands.  Management is conscience of this and supports as  best as they can.

job_title: Senior Academic Advisor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The laid back atmosphere isn't too stressful and the health and dental benefits are in alignment with other universities where I've worked. Public transportation is readily available and easy and there are numerous dining options available to students and staff. There is ever present construction on campus, which some might see as a negative, but it means the university is growing and upgrading.
cons: Although a large state university many of the departments and offices still run as if they are smaller private liberal arts colleges. The campus definitely doesn't feel very collegiate and parking on campus can be difficult. Pay is good, but not competitive with other surrounding universities, especially coupled with the cost of living in Philadelphia.

review_title: Cyclical business with perks of a university/college environment.  Feel young and energized for projects.
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Philadelphia, PA
pros: College Spirit and atmosphere can be addictive.  Events for students include staff, such as Spring Fling carnivals, etc.  These events are a welcome break to the daily work load.  Some offices have a family/friends type of atmosphere in and outside of work.  Plenty of eating and transportation options.
cons: Politics and Bureaucracy.  Shear size can sometimes make projects difficult to get consensus and done.  The 'temple runaround' when you need to get something done, it usually results in several office visits/phone calls.  But this has gotten much better the past few years.

pros: Some students are great.
cons: Students are very underprepared for a real academic environment. No intellectual culture in certain departments. Curricula more for high school level than college. No job security. Low pay. No training. Adjuncts are evaluated by student feedback forms only, not faculty or peer evaluations.  Incentives to inflate grades and suck up to students - as opposed to offering a real intellectual experience. Creates weird power structure. Sloppy HR practices. Sketchy communication. Stay away and work for another school.

pros:
-Depending on your PI, you will have freedom in scientific research, flexible hours.
-Temple follows NIH guidelines for postdoc salaries. So at least you won't be paid less than that. You can always ask your PI for a higher salary.
-Newly formed Postdoc Association
-Sponsors for H1B visa
-Good health insurance
cons:
- Postdocs are neither students nor staff, often fall through the cracks. All the issues associated with being a postdoc (in general) exist here as well.
- Some administrative staff is completely incompetent
-No retirement benefits
-No professional development opportunities for postdocs

pros: Applying my organizational and problem-solving skills was a an exhilarating challenge during years of change at the college I worked for. I loved helping students, faculty, parents, and advisors navigate the complexities of university policy and procedure. It was gratifying to know that I was THE go-to person for the college and working with people that knew that I was someone to rely on.
cons: Changes were made that reduced my role to not much more than data entry after over six years of being integral to holding down the fort during multiple transitions.

review_title: Overall, a fantastic environment for student workers
pros: The atmosphere is great, and because you're working in an academic environment, generally, coworkers and service users are respectful of you opinions. Also, feedback given to superiors is generally taken into account when considering or implementing changes in job-essential processes.
cons: Scheduling can sometimes be erratic, and there are times when other student coworkers forget they are scheduled to work, causing confusion during shift changes.

pros: Great teaching hospital and the people are very friendly.  The nursing, physicians and pharmacy departments worked very well towards effective patient care.
cons: Middle management was not well trained for leadership positions as they did not follow the mission and values of the Temple University Hospital System.  Communications in the IT department were discouraged from the inpatient team verses the ambulatory team serving the electronic medical record.

job_title: CST Peer Tutor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I worked as a part time peer tutor for the College of Science and Technology, and I enjoyed taking control of my role as a tutor. I was free to sign up for office hours that I felt I could commit to the entire semester, and controlled my method of tutoring during those hours. HR was a pleasure to work with, and always responded quickly. Overall, I very much enjoyed my time as a peer tutor!
cons: The only con is that the equipment in the peer tutoring room was poor, and sometimes did not fully turn on for timely clock-in's.

pros:
Employees and their children can receive free educations from non-professional schools.
On-site free medical clinic.
Good health insurance and retirement plans.
Easy commute via subway and bus lines.
cons:
Pay is below-scale for technical people.
Vision plan is sub-standard.
Promotions and training are only for those who are  "in the clique".  Heavy duty nepotism is the norm and is referred to as "the Temple Way".
Clique members tend to harass outsiders with assignment overloads, ostracism, and snide remarks.  
Team work is defined as 2 cliquers are "in charge", 1 clique-outsider does all the actual work.

pros:
-Benefits for family planning and education
-Work with students, if that's your thing
-Connections in higher academia
cons:
-inflexible hours and no opportunity for raises or overtime.
-"Other duties as applies" clause means you will be doing tasks not aligned with your paid responsibilities
-prioritization of students and parents over workers. So you will constantly have to record interactions with students to cover yourself in case. 
-depending on work load you may be pressured out of using your time off.

pros: Temple University is a very diverse school and offers great pay. It also has a beautiful campus with plenty of interesting people and professors. I learned a great deal from this place.
cons: Starting salaries are the pits. They really value seniority here so you may have to work for about five to ten years minimum to see a decent pay raise

pros: A steady paycheck.  You stay as long as you want.  No one really wants to fire anyone for incompetence.  A typical large institution type employer.  If you are smart and keep away from politics, definitely good way to earn your way to retirement
cons: There isn't a lot of room for advancement.  Don't expect any large bonus.  Depending on your department, it could get a good boss and love your work or a bad one and get stuck.  In general, I would say leadership needs more training on how to be a good manager

pros: The benefits were very good and I had no problems with my time off or medical insurance.  My hours were pretty flexible and the staff were very friendly.
cons: Sometimes administration were a little haphazard.  I worked in research up at the medical school and the salary wasn't the best.  Also, you have to be careful working in north philadelphia.

review_title: Temple Health System provides excellent care and has top docs in their fields, but overall has poor business practices.
pros: Good salary and benefits; comprehensive, low cost health care for employees; nice co-workers; convenient location; respected and well renown organization.
cons: Poor business practices; lack of enforcing business and human resource policies; very little training; weak middle management, lack of staff recognition for accomplishments.

review_title: Once an adj. ALWAYS an adj. Temple's policy is to NEVER hire f/t professors from the pool of highly qual. adjuncts.
pros: The students are the best reason to work at Temple. IF you're lucky enough to get hired on full time as either faculty or some kind of staff (ie: security, adminstrative, publications, etc.) I understand the pay is decent and the health benefits and time time off are excellent. Of course, if you love being part of a serious, competetive research university, right in the center of a bustling metropolis, then Temple's a good spot for you.
cons:
Personally for me, it's about respect, and it's about money. It's being hired full-time instead of being fed crumbs off of the table after others enjoy the feast. More broadly, it's that Temple University just isn't serious about hiring qualified instructors and staff even as they march on like some heedless brat in sandbox gleefully squashing old (sometimes decrepit, it's true)  neighborhoods to then build brand new shining towers that they can neither equip or fill with the proper amount of staff and faculty. They're operating just like all of the massive new "super-hospitals" or "mega-health systems" that are springing up all over the East coast in that they are building facilities but don't h have the real money required to HIRE qualified people (ie: doctors, nurses, x-ray, and nuke techs) but if they COULD actually afford to hire people and open the new wings and towers, then patients would enjoy a private room with a view.
Temple though, is about to suffer a major "ROI" issue because its reputation as a "Student-first" school is about to tumble. The adminstrations wants the departments to  mainly use tired, overworked and definitely UNDERPAID part-timers and low-wage "gypsy" profs like me to teach the majority of the classes. That is NO  way to run a university considering how expensive they are. People are looking for a deal and unless Temple wakes up and starts treating its employees better and starts hiriing and getting folks benefits, then their reputatin will proceed them and parents and students will choose the university with the most Full Time instructors who are committed professionals with health care and paid vacation.

review_title: Great place to get started, but salaries and career opportunity is limited
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Lots of tools at your disposal and a good dojo to learn stuff.  They use everything from .Net to Java to PHP, and a lot of server side and scripting going on.  You have an audience of over 70k student and 10k employees that will use the software you write.  You will never take work home with you, when you go home, it's done.  If you want vacation time, their policy is generous.  There are some really nice folks that work there as well.
cons: Politics, politics, politics.  Salaries are generally slanted heavily towards those with advanced degrees, and those who came "during the good times".  There is a ton of "dead wood", it definitely feels like a government job.  With the state budgets being slashed year after year, they are always scrambling to figure out how they will keep everyone employed, no less award the ones doing good work.  You won't likely be noticed if you're doing a great, and likewise if you're doing  a bad job.  If you are likeable enough, they'll keep you around even if you can't write a line of code that runs on your own, especially if your family is connected somehow.  The ones who write software that saves tons of money are kept in their role and not given any increases, the increases that do come are very modest.  Middle managers are scared to death of the younger generation who knows software engineering, it's almost like they don't want great "doers".  If you don't care about your salary that much, maybe this is an ok job for you to just sit and tinker on stuff and learn.  They will give you a bunch of time to do even the most menial task at times, other times they will ask you to write some crazy mission critical thing in a week without tests, the project management is kind of non existent.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: its on-campus so you don't have to waste money on travel. Flexible hours. Had great co-workers. Gained many skills as I interacted with different kinds of people. This location was a hub for getting to know students from different parts of the world and enable me to be in a position to help them navigate the stressful event of finding where to stay and adjusting to new environment.
cons: because you are in a customer service department, sometimes you have to deal with rude callers. Some administration issues can be a challenge when things get changed last minute.

job_title: Computer Consultant in New Phila, PA
pros:
Working as computer tech consultant gives you these following add in to your career.
Good exposure, Technical expertise enhancement, challenging, enhancement of service and people skills
cons: Working as computer tech consultant may be hectic at some times. Working under too many managers leads to mis communication and affects in overall efficiency. Limited overall growth opportunity is another thing which comes in my mind working in such arena.

pros: Benefits, 403(b) match... Temple gave 8.5% to my retirement and all i had to give was 4.5%.  we were given the best technology with which to work.  the working conditions were good and almost everyone in my area had there own office.  there were no cublicles - which is very good.
cons: poor supervisors and managers; promotion based on favortism

review_title: A great university in a terrible location.
pros: The pay is competitive. The student body is diverse. Working for Temple allows one to access the full potential of the city of Philadelphia. Unlike a small college town, the city offers connections that can allow upward mobility in fields outside of academia.
cons: North Philadelphia is not a proper place for a major state university. The university is located in one of the worst areas in the city. The campus is clean, safe, and beautiful but the reality of poverty and crime is only a stones throw a way at any time.

job_title: Research Specialist Pulmonary in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Friendly staff, good colleagues,good benefits if you work full time.
cons: Too much work, no over time. No equal distribution of work. No performance based bonuses or raises. Unexpected lay offs and short notices, incompetent management

review_title: Meh. Very little onboarding support. Lack of transparency.
pros: The students are generally great. Scrappy, inquisitive, down-to-earth. Lots of freedom to design curriculum. Relatively few bureaucratic expectations for adjuncts.
cons: Almost NO mentorship or development. Very little connection to fellow faculty. Low pay when you factor in class prep and grading, etc. NO job security whatsoever. Constant threat of being not renewed for ambiguous criteria. Very little feedback/ review. No health benefits or opportunity for advancement for adjuncts, even after many years of continuous employment.

review_title: Good benefits, if you're willing to endure bad service
pros: The benefits are outstanding if you can stomach going to the Episcopal Hospital, which is located in a terrible part of town. In fact, most of Temple's locations are in pretty horrible areas, but they make the most of it. The buy-in from administration on helping students is exemplary.
cons: Lots of staff change-over, which makes it hard to get to know anyone; some supervisors are more hands-off than others, which makes it appear dysfunctional at times.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
You get to be in direct contact with your mentor and the PhD candidates you work close with. 
You push yourself to read more research papers. 
Learn more techniques in solving problems.
I was able to learn how research is conducted, data analysis importance in research, in addition to some hands on experience with matlab with couple PhD students from the electrical department.
cons: Too Mach time sitting in front of computer tracking cells, taking notes, and collecting data for analysis. Hard to keep up with especially if you are full time student.

review_title: Beautiful place with an amazing mission but with poor career opportunities for those who want to be succesful
pros: Amazing people who really want to change the university. Great Ideology behind their mission. Free education- MBA/ Masters. No micro management
cons: poor training; lack of communication, too much politics; if you want to succeed in your career, you are better off starting in corporate world and work for Temple once you already have tons of experience because you will not learn much here. Low pay.

review_title: Your satisfaction will depend on what you're looking for.
pros:
Temple is a great place if:
- You value health insurance above salary
- You want your kids to (eventually) attend Temple
- You want to earn an advanced degree
- You're looking for a more laid-back atmosphere
- You're looking for a job with an excellent work/life balance
cons:
Temple is a non-profit higher education facility, so it's not great for:
- Climbing the corporate ladder
- Earning performance bonuses, promotions, or raises
- Working on innovative products and pushing the envelope.

review_title: A decent place to work, but not without it's flaws
pros: A well paying job for education.  Encourages a good work/life balance.  Good benefits; with ample vacation time and top-notch healthcare.
cons: Limited upward mobility for technical staff.  There is a culture of micromanagement and heavy bureaucracy.  Changes and new projects are often dictated from above, frequently without properly consulting the staff which will implement and support these projects.

pros: Room and Board is paid for which is a great convenience. The residents and administration are also very reliable and fun to work with.
cons: The job can be very over whelming and high stress. You will deal with crisis management on a regular basis whether that be on a person to person or on a building wide scale.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
+ There are many departments of medical research to choose from. 
+ Reasonable amount of independence as an investigator
+ Good benefits (health insurance)
+ Multiple seminars and opportunities to present research
cons:
- Postdoctoral salary
- Surrounding area is not the safest. 
- Garage parking available for $110/month
- Expect long hours in research

pros: Worked in center city location and enjoyed it very much. Management was extremely knowledgeable and took time to mentor and create a great bond with the student workers.
cons: Some of the work hours could be tough, but they worked with you to work around your class schedule. Some of the students could be extremely rude, but that is not the job's fault.

pros: Temple is not an easy place to attend and work for, but the experience you get from doing so is worth it. The diversity does a lot for your interpersonal growth because you have to interact with so many people from so many different cultural backgrounds.
cons: Of course, the North Philadelphia area is nothing to boast about but if you give people the chance, they will surprise you.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Because Temple is so diverse and full of education-loving people, it is a great working environment. My co-workers were all energetic and passionate, and I never had any issues with them or administration.
cons: It can be difficult/lengthy to get reimbursed for traveling expenses. Vacation days for holidays can be timed poorly and can impede with the work. Some time is wasted with administrative actions.

pros: It is a public University, so the job comes with all the benefits it entails. Great health insurance, 401K, retirement accounts etc. And also having access to all of the University's resources like the gym/pool, public spaces, events etc is great.
cons: The culture is really not the best. They're still living in the 80's, oblivious to the goings on of the rest of the world. Don't expect flexible hours, or WFH benefits. But the biggest drawback is the highly non-competitive salaries, and 0 career growth.

review_title: Not a university atmosphere for the Computer Services Department
pros: Can't beat their benefits, including tuition remission, medical, dental, vision, the week between Christmas and New Year's off, etc.  The benefits package and perks make up for the not-so-competitive pay that most universities have.
cons: At the computer services department, the culture is almost 1980's corporate.  A lot of micro-managing, flex time is rare, you have to clock in and out, working remotely is non-existent, unless you are working from home after-hours.

pros: Great pay and benefits.  Good opportunities for for lateral experiences and for advancement.  Very diverse population of patients.  Chance to work with advanced medicine practices and excellent physicians.  For those concerned with safety - their security department is outstanding and have received the same training as the Philadelphia Police Department.
cons: Parking was an issue, but the University has built a state of the art parking garage and has developed other smaller lots that employees are assigned to.

pros: Great benefits, Full tuition remission. Excellent Health insurance. Vested after 3 years company match stock. Great vibrant atmosphere plenty of time off.
cons: Too many meeting, too much red tape to cut through. Pay is very low. HR is a nightmare, take very long time to get hired. Just do some research figure out who the real hiring manager is and by-bass HR send resume directly to them.

pros: Great people to work with, pay and benefits are unbeatable. They offer tuition grants to go back to school or for your family.  The vacation time is very generous.
cons: The administrators are overworked and stretched to thin.  It shows in how they treat their staff.  They can sometimes be short or disrespectful to those they are managing.

review_title: This is a great university which gives you so many opportunities to realize yourself.
pros: As for a full time student the pay is Ok. University allows you to open your mind.  Working for Temple gives you an opportunity to network with many students and professors.
cons: Although there are many police officers around, the location of the university is not the safest one in the Philadelphia area.  Every week you will receive an "alert message" that a robbery occurred neat the Temple.

pros: I loved the people I worked with at Temple, particularly my immediate supervisor.  My schedule was flexible even though the work tended to pile up.
cons: I got laid off because my department was so poorly funded they couldn't pay my meager wages.  It hurts knowing the Fox School can afford to put in marble steps because there's nothing better to spend money on, but in other parts of the university people are struggling to make ends meet.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: A great place to learn, grow, have great discussions with culturally diverse people. A great place to personally and professionally grow. Love the students, the full-time staff is supportive when you ask for it.
cons: As an adjunct the pay is less than desirable, yet the work is great.

pros: Decent compensation; excellent benefits, especially matching 403B
cons: Disorganized and inefficient management; inexperienced managers and directors; outdated policies and procedures; incompetent HR. Senior management does not recognize middle management's and staff's suggestions.

pros: Great "kids", relative autonomy for lesson planning and the myriad other things that are often over"managed" by admin.
cons: Great hourly pay BUT, they keep you under 18 hours / week so TU doesn't have to pay benefits, etc. = at full 18 credit teaching load = about, or less than, $500 / week take home. Try living on that in PhilaPA.

pros: Diverse, growing graduate programs, expanding labs and equipment, renovating building, hiring new faculties.
cons: Not enough collaboration with outside, growing slowly

job_title: Instructional Assistant Professor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I love the people that I work with, in my department and college, and those I've met from across campus. They are dedicated and wonderful. The benefits are good, too.
cons: Administration places little value on teaching, and none on teaching faculty. This may vary by college, but in mine we are underpaid, undervalued and underrepresented in every decision-making process.

pros: This is a good company to work for.  They treat their employees fair, and have excellent benefits.  The work schedule is flexible.
cons: It is not in the best of neighboorhoods and parking around campus can be a choir.  Also, the university rarely closes other than major holidays.

job_title: Study Abroad Coordinator in Philadelphia, PA
pros: I was a student there and being around my teachers and other students all day is perfect. Go TEMPLE OWLS!
cons: You don't always get to work with who you would like to and due to Budget cuts in education some departments tend to suffer more than others. Sad

review_title: It was really good experience working at Temple University
pros: They give perfect amount of work so we get time for little bit study during job hours also the flexible schedule so study or class won't affect, they also gives raise after every certain amount of time
cons: I can't think of anything but I think it's little bit hard to get a job as a student worker if you don't have any contacts of hiring managers or other student workers.

review_title: 24 yrs of all aspects of medical clerical experience
pros: good job with good benefits  management was very good and fair i believed.worked as a team doing work on a daily basis , fast and accurate
cons: stressfull at times when we were short staffed,however the work had to be done and was all the time every day in time no matter what

pros: Really appreciated the department I worked with, all of the directors and advisors were so friendly and cooperative. Management is so easy to communicate with. Learning skills and gaining extra opportunities were abundant.
cons: Big university means that policies often change, would be nice to be more consistent. Departments often bounce students around, because they assume they don't have the capabilities to help, which was super annoying.

pros: The co-workers in my department are a plus, for the most part.  My direct supervisor is amazing.  Flexibility of working time is also a plus.
cons: Many people get paid salaries much lower than the general average for their position.  Union is not always there for you when you need them.

pros: I have been working at Temple University since 2012 either as Teaching assistant or research assistant. It is nice place to work. They have been improving buildings.
cons: The neighborhood around Temple is not so good. Sometimes it can be dangerous to walk around Temple University. However, Temple Police is always around.

review_title: This is just about Temple engineering school
pros: Locates in the city, great access, alive campus, high end tech center and study areas, diverse environments
cons: Engineering school doesn't have enough TAship and RAship to support PhD students for the most of their study.

review_title: Temple is a wonderful place to work because Temple employer they  do not just train you.They train you for life.
pros: Temple is surround by a lot postive history, a loving active community. From Temple to the street Templ know you by your name.
cons: I can not think of any cons. If I haf to say something then I would say no matter what conner you walk to you will always find someone that you know.

review_title: Good experience until new president took over.
pros: Great coworkers. Great students. Beautiful campus. Very efficient facility services.
cons: Too much emphasis on attracting wealthy students. Too little emphasis on working within the local community. Too little concern with negative impact of students on local community.

review_title: Working at Temple was very rewarding and I got to work with some wonderfully brilliant people.
pros: Great food, eat at the cheap food trucks. I was part-time but I heard the benefits are amazing.
cons: I really don't have many negative things to say. I guess it being a big bureaucracy makes things a little difficult.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Flexible, good students. Lots of opportunity to teach. No need for Ph.D. Both day and night courses. great facilities.
cons: not much training. You are a little on your own with the curriculum. Sometimes courses can have too many students

review_title: I love working at Temple but the department in which I work is gender biased
pros: Students, faculty members, intellectually stimulating, good tuition benefits, academic environment
cons: Hiring freeze for 3-4 years has contributed to increased job responsibilities for salaried (non-bargaining positions) employees.  Freeze on salary increases for non-bargaining staff for several years with increased employee contributions for healthcare.

review_title: OK though can certainly be better
pros: Benefits, especially health care.  Some flexibility in work hours, but during semesters full teaching load can easily result in 60 hours week with no paid overtime, of course.
cons: low pay, career advancement for non-tenure track faculty are almost nonexistent. It can only happen via success in research.

pros: good administration, great support from Professors, people willing to collaborate and help you with your work, night owl commuting system, big university with multiple levels of education offered
cons: the location where it is located is unsafe, no strong graduate association that helps incoming graduates with accommodation etc., safety for electronics inside the building (in offices etc) is not great

pros: Super convenient for students, great way to get to know administrators and learn about Temple processes, depending on which office you're in the work might be minimal.
cons: Low pay, not very exciting or challenging, very difficult to navigate the student jobs portal system if you don't already know an administrator/ someone in the office.

pros: Flexible schedule in my department.  If you suggest an idea, and it's decided to be good, you're expected to follow through to complete it.  Benefits are good.  Tuition remission a bonus.  Diverse campus.
cons: Segregated departments.  No room for advancement.  Grant funded program so pay was low.  Creativity and initiative not supported.

pros: Was allowed to contribute my work, and opinions.  Could work at my own pace and had ample time to finish my work.
cons: It was the same routine everyday, which got boring after a while.  I needed some change in my routine to keep me interested.

pros: Starting salaries for librarians are competitive.  The appallingly low starting salaries at some of the nearby institutions kept me from relocating to Philly sooner.  All the usual perks apply, e.g. good health benefits, tuition remission, extended Christmas break...  Lots of interesting degree programs and activities.
cons: Hierarchy rules all and can stifle creativity.  Campus is ugly.

pros: Location in Philadelphia a major north eastern city near all of the major research centers, including the Library of Congress and National Archives.
cons: Lack of faculty diversity in most humanities and other university departments with the exception of African American Studies.

pros: Great job, great benefits, great environment.  There are multiple IT managers thought the university since most of the individual schools have their own IT group.
cons: Salary trends towards lower end of the scale when starting or getting promotions. You actually end up making more money if you were to leave the university and come back a few years later.

review_title: A fantastic learning experience and awesome career opportunity.
job_title: Biomedical Equipment Technician in South Pittsburg, TN
pros: The Salary and benefits are awesome. The experience was life changing. I very much enjoyed going to work everyday.
cons: It’s a challenge trying to be the other genders equal. There are changes that need to be addressed and acknowledged and not swept under the rug when it comes to gender discrimination!

pros: Acedemic rigor and community, great fringe benefits, schoiol pride from improvements over the years and great sport teams (yes football is coming back), full curricullam -- Most of all once you are in the Temple family you are really in the family and can count on your peers to support you.
cons: Dependency on State funds curb the school's freedom

pros: good and liked the staff and it was great to have the ability to work and be a student at the same time
cons: i didn't find any cons but the hourly pay could have been more. i liked the people i worked for and the hours were good

review_title: You won't get rich but may profit greatly
pros: Great community, great mission, and great benefits, including the healthcare and tuition remission.
cons: Low salaries. Your experience will depend on what you're doing and where you're doing it. Temple is like a city within a city, with a variety of colleges, units, and programs. Is your job a union job or not? Are you teaching, or an administrator? And so on.

pros: Temple is grate place to work.  Most people don't leave.  Some of the pros are your Co-workers, the technology, and your work-life balance
cons: Universities in general are well known for below market compensation.  I see a lot of people saying that they don't know what the future hold with regards to career opportunities.

job_title: Lab Technician I in Philadelphia, PA
pros: At one time it was a great place to work growth learning opportunity wise
cons: New management is not too great they went from being supportive and all about the employee to a very punishment like atmosphere it went from a 9 to a 1 very quickly

pros: Temple has a pretty robust marketing and communications program. There are many options for students to form a foundation for a marketing career. The students are - for the most part - motivated, focused and energetic.
cons: Some students could use more guidance and insights into honing their courses to better focus on areas of specialty.

pros:
- Fun and engaging, great coworkers
- Great work-life balance with plenty of PTO and 2 weeks off over Christmas when the University is closed
- Good health/dental benefits
- Easy going, I wasn't micromanaged at all
cons:
- Pay is standard for a University meaning salaries are low, especially for living in the city
- Can be bureaucratic depending on your department, managers tend to pick favorites

job_title: Education Coordinator in Forty Fort, PA
pros: Health Insurance was great, pay was decent for the job
cons: Very political, lots of promotion within for mediocre work. The sense of community/collaboration wasn't great, didn't get the sense you were ever cared for or you were valued

pros: Good pay, little liberal in nature, inside campus is very diverse and beautiful, good restaurants, full security inside the campus
cons: Not safe area where college is situated ( I am in main campus), supervisor doesn't have clear idea what they want. Definitely not a very good place for achieving extra skills as a post doc if you have a very good PhD background and good papers!

pros: They are one of the better paying facilities!
cons: There are so many issues that I wouldn't recommend anyone to work here. Unorganized, no sense of job security, obvious favoritism, good workers are not appreciated /get taken advantage of, no room for growth because they bring in who they know and promote their friends (some without the experience or knowledge) and the list goes on.

review_title: It is good to be a student worker in Temple
